section.title: Databases
section.para: You need to create regular backups of the following databases on the host where the Monitoring Service is installed:
It is recommended that backup and restore operations for databases are carried out by experienced operators only.
For backing up and restoring your Elasticsearch database, you can use the Snapshot and Restore module of Elasticsearch.
To make a backup of the database, proceed as follows:

listitem.para:
Make sure that curl is installed. If this is not the case, download and install it, for example, from the following Web site:
http://curl.haxx.se/download.html .
Log in to the host where the Monitoring Service is installed.
The example registers a shared file system repository ("type": "fs") that uses the /mount/backup/elasticsearch1 directory for storing snapshots.

note.para: The directory for storing snapshots must be specified as configured during the installation of the Monitoring Service in the group_vars/monasca_group file. The directory must be manually mounted before creating the snapshot. The elastic user must be specified as the owner of the directory.

listitem.para: compress is turned on to compress the metadata files.
Check whether the repository was created successfully.
Example response for a successfully created repository:

Create a snapshot of your database that contains all indices. A repository can contain multiple snapshots of the same database. The name of a snapshot must be unique within the snapshots created for your database.
The example creates a snapshot named snapshot_1 for all indices in the my_backup repository.

section.para: To restore the database instance, proceed as follows:

listitem.para: Close all indices of your database.
Restore all indices from the snapshot you have created.
The example restores all indices from snapshot_1 that is stored in the my_backup repository.

section.para:
For additional information backing up and restoring an Elasticsearch database, refer to the
Elasticsearch documentation .

For backing up and restoring your InfluxDB database, you can use the InfluxDB shell. The shell is part of your InfluxDB distribution. If you installed InfluxDB via a package manager, the shell is, by default, installed in the /usr/bin directory.
To make a backup of the database, proceed as follows:

listitem.para: Log in to the InfluxDB database as a user who is allowed to run the influxdb service.
Replace <db_name> with the name of the database. The example creates the backup for the database in /mount/backup/mysnapshot.

If required, delete all files not included in the backup by dropping the database before you carry out the restore operation. A restore operation restores all files included in the backup. Files created or merged at a later point in time are not affected.

For backing up and restoring your MariaDB database, you can use the mysqldump utility program. mysqldump performs a logical backup that produces a set of SQL statements. These statements can later be executed to restore the database.
To back up your MariaDB database, you must be the owner of the database or a user with superuser privileges. You can use the following command.
In addition to the name of the database, you have to specify the name and the location where mysqldump stores its output.
To restore your MariaDB database, proceed as follows:

listitem.para: Log in to the host where the Monitoring Service is installed as a user with root privileges.
Go to the directory where the SUSE OpenStack Cloud Monitoring installation package is located.
Log in to the database you have backed up as a user with root privileges.
